channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Netanyahu and Biden Voice Divisions Over War’s Next Steps
item.description: In his sharpest rebuke to date, President Biden said Israel was losing the world’s support, speaking after Prime Minister Netanyahu said he would not allow the Palestinian Authority to take over Gaza after the war.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesting in Sanaa, Yemen, this month to show support for Palestinians in Gaza.

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: As Zelensky Pleads for Aid, Republicans Demand Border Concessions From Biden
item.description: Ukraine’s president is in Washington with an urgent request for more help to fight Russia, but Republicans in both chambers say they won’t act without a border deal. Mr. Zelensky will meet soon with President Biden.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine arriving at the Capitol on Tuesday, where he earned a show of support from Senators Chuck Schumer and Mitch McConnell

item.title: How Africans Are Changing French — One Joke, Rap and Book at a Time
item.description: More than 60 percent of French speakers now live in Africa. Despite growing resentment at France, Africans are contributing to the evolution and spread of the French language.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier, Arlette Bashizi and Hannah Reyes Morales
item.media:credit: Arlette Bashizi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Standup comedian Jacques Silvère Bah, known as Le Magnific, played with French and African words and accents at a humor festival in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, in February.

item.title: Israel Evacuation Orders in Gaza Sow Confusion
item.description: Even Gazans who can get access to Israeli directions online say they sometimes make no sense, which could be a matter of life or death.
item.dc:creator: Yara Bayoumy, Lauren Leatherby and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:description: Salvaging materials on Saturday from a building hit by an Israeli strike in Khan Younis, Gaza.

item.title: At Least 23 Soldiers Killed in Attack in Pakistan
item.description: Tensions have been rising between Pakistan and Afghanistan, and violence in the border area has increased since Pakistan directed all undocumented foreigners to leave the country.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: Rescue workers examined damage at the site of an explosion on the outskirts of Dera Ismail Khan, Pakistan, on Tuesday.

item.title: Leader of Elite French University Offers to Step Aside, for Now
item.description: Mathias Vicherat, the director of Sciences Po, has exchanged accusations of domestic violence with his partner. The police are investigating.
item.dc:creator: Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle
item.media:description: Students at Sciences Po staged a sit-in on campus last week to demand the resignation of Mathias Vicherat, the director of the university. The banner reads, “Protected aggressors, abandoned victims, Sciences Po, paradise of impunity.”

item.title: Kyivstar, Ukraine’s Largest Mobile Operator, Is Hit by a Cyberattack
item.description: The interruption could pose real danger in a country where many rely on phone alerts to warn them of impending Russian bombardments.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: The headquarters of Kyivstar in Ukraine’s capital. The company said it was working to restore service after it was hit by a cyberattack.

item.title: Finland Partly Reopens Its Border With Russia
item.description: The Nordic country, which recently joined NATO, has accused Moscow of funneling migrants to their shared land border.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The Vaalimaa crossing between Finland and Russia last week. The countries’ relationship deteriorated markedly after Moscow’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: France Plans to Lure FIFA With Promise of Tax-Free Home
item.description: A plan to persuade sports federations to move to the country could save them millions. Supporters and critics of the proposal say it is intended to tempt one governing body in particular.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Daphné Anglès
item.media:description: FIFA headquarters in Zurich, the organization’s home since 1932.

item.title: Zulu King’s Reign Is in Doubt After South Africa Court Ruling
item.description: King Misuzulu’s claim to the throne in a storied monarchy has been the subject of a bitter family feud. The drama has captivated a nation that is home to about 14 million Zulus.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: King Misuzulu in September. A judge’s ruling in South Africa has raised fresh questions over his claim to the Zulu throne.

item.title: Three Months After Biden, It’s Xi’s Turn to Court Vietnam
item.description: The Chinese leader wants assurances that the strategically important country isn’t taking Washington’s side against Beijing, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Luong Thai Linh
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, and his wife, Peng Liyuan, arriving in Hanoi on Tuesday.

item.title: UK Parliament’s Rwanda Vote Today, Explained
item.description: The British prime minister faces a test of his authority as a divided Parliament prepares to vote on his flagship immigration policy.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has made halting the arrival of migrants on the British coast in small vessels into a central test of his premiership.

item.title: After Referee Attack, Turkey Suspends All Soccer Matches
item.description: The postgame attack shocked a country used to heated atmospheres at soccer matches. The team president who threw the punch was arrested and later resigned his post.
item.dc:creator: James Montague
item.media:credit: Abdurrahman Antakyali/Depo Photos, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The referee Halil Umut Meler covered his face after being punched and knocked to the ground by Faruk Koca, center, the president of the Ankaragucu soccer club.

item.title: Biden Says Israel Is Losing War Support, Rebuking Netanyahu
item.description: President Biden told donors that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel must “strengthen and change” his government.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden described the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as “the most conservative government in Israel’s history.”

item.title: U.N. Seeks Repayment of $63.6 Million From Former Official
item.description: The official was fired after investing millions in U.N. funds in housing and energy projects that went badly. He is contesting the order.
item.dc:creator: David A. Fahrenthold and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Vitaly Vanshelboim in 2016. He has been ordered to repay millions to the U.N. after he lost vast amounts of funds.

item.title: NOAA’s Arctic Report Card for 2023
item.description: Observations from researchers and residents, published annually in a report by NOAA, reveal a region grappling with rapid change.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:description: Ice in eastern Greenland: The continent’s ice sheet has lost mass every year since 1998.

item.title: Lawmakers Call for Raising Tariffs and Severing Economic Ties With China
item.description: A bipartisan report recommended stripping China of the low tariffs the United States granted it two decades ago, among other actions.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A car assembly line in China. Many of the report’s recommendations may never be adopted, but it could provide a path toward some bipartisan legislation on China in the months to come.

item.title: All 7 Members of BTS Are Now in Military Service in South Korea
item.description: The last two members, Jimin and Jungkook, began their 18-month military duty in South Korea on Tuesday. Some fans say they should have been exempt.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: BTS fans gathering outside a military facility in Nonsan, South Korea, on Monday,

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Skirmishes between Israel and Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Smoke rising above the outskirts of Yaroun, a Lebanese village near the border with Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: How Abigail Echo-Hawk Uses Indigenous Data to Close the Equity Gap
item.description: The public health researcher Abigail Echo-Hawk is a leading voice in a movement to empower Indigenous people, wielding data as a tool for racial equity.
item.media:description: Abigail Echo-Hawk is a leading voice of the Indigenous data movement. She uses data to dismantle stereotypes, highlight disparities and vie for funding.

item.title: Houthi Militia Attacks Ship Near the Red Sea, Pentagon Says
item.description: The attack was the latest by the group on targets in the Red Sea and the broader region during more than two months of war between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang, Livia Albeck-Ripka and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: An oil tanker moored in the Red Sea, off the coast of the western Yemen in July.

item.title: Israel, Fighting Hamas in Gaza, Warns Hezbollah, Too
item.description: Top Israeli officials hinted at a powerful response to attacks by Hezbollah across the northern border with Lebanon, as to the south Israeli troops wage street battles against Hamas in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez, Neil MacFarquhar and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Northern Gaza on Monday during an Israeli bombardment.

item.title: Glenys Kinnock, Political Force in Britain and Europe, Dies at 79
item.description: The wife of the Labour leader Neil Kinnock, she carved her own leftist identity with a seat in the European Parliament and as a British government minister.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.media:credit: Salvatore Di Nolfi/Keystone, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Glenys Kinnock in 2010. Her career included serving for 15 years as a socialist member of the European Parliament, specializing in international development.

item.title: Hamas Strongholds Targeted by Israel: Khan Younis, Jabaliya and Shajaiye
item.description: Israeli forces were engaged in intense battles on Monday in Khan Younis, Jabaliya and Shajaiye.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Rosenberg
item.media:description: Destroyed homes in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. and Ukraine Search for a New Strategy After Failed Counteroffensive
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky arrived in Washington at a critical moment, both on the battlefield and on Capitol Hill.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt, David E. Sanger and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The United States has given vast military and economic support to Ukraine in its war with Russia over the past two years.

item.title: Macron Suffers Surprise Setback Over Immigration in France
item.description: The country’s lower house of Parliament unexpectedly passed a motion to reject a government immigration reform bill, leaving its future uncertain.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Interior Minister Gérald Darmanin of France addresses the French National Assembly on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Raises Concern Over Israel’s Possible Use of U.S.-Supplied White Phosphorus
item.description: The Biden administration said it would be asking questions about reports of Israel illegally using white phosphorus in Lebanon in October. Israel denied the claims.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Shells that appear to be white phosphorus explode over Dahaira, a Lebanese border village with Israel, on Oct. 16.

item.title: ‘We Are All Sick’: Infectious Diseases Spread Across Gaza
item.description: Cold, wet weather combined with a lack of clean water, toilets and food have fueled a spike in respiratory, stomach and other ailments, and the sick are left struggling to recover, health officials say.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta, Hiba Yazbek and Ameera Harouda
item.media:description: Palestinians collecting water in Khan Younis in southern Gaza on Monday. Access to clean water and food is scarce in the overcrowded shelters.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: An Israeli Warning to Hezbollah
item.description: Plus, the debate over who’s a “colonizer.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:description: Smoke rose from town of Khan Younis after Israeli strikes on Sunday.

item.title: U.N. Cuts Appeal for Aid Despite Deepening Crises
item.description: With pledges already lagging badly for this year, the global organization said that it had been forced to pare down its request for 2024 to focus on only the most life-threatening cases.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: A tent camp for displaced families in Khan Yunis, in the southern Gaza Strip, last month. Most of Gaza’s 2.2 million residents have been forced to leave their homes in the war with Israel.

item.title: Donald Tusk Chosen as Poland’s Prime Minister After Rival Is Rejected
item.description: Parliament shot down a new government proposed by the caretaker prime minister, Mateusz Morawiecki, whose party, Law and Justice, lost its parliamentary majority in an October election.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: The leader of Poland’s opposition, Donald Tusk, center, after legislators rejected a new government proposed by the caretaker prime minister, Mateusz Morawiecki, on Monday.

item.title: Iran Puts Johan Floderus, E.U. Official From Sweden, on Trial
item.description: The European Union and Sweden have called for the immediate release of Johan Floderus, who has been detained in Tehran for about 600 days.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: In an image released by the Mizan news agency, which is overseen by Iran’s judiciary, Johan Floderus, a European Union official from Sweden, attended a court session in Tehran on Sunday.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Faces One of His Toughest Weeks as U.K. Prime Minister
item.description: The prime minister testified at an official inquiry into the Covid pandemic on Monday while also defending a flagship immigration policy from rebels in his own party.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak arriving at a hearing on Britain’s Covid response, during which he denied clashing with his predecessor Boris Johnson.

item.title: As Zelensky Heads to Washington, Russia Targets Kyiv With Missiles
item.description: The Ukrainian leader will be appealing for more military support from the United States as an emboldened Russia steps up its attacks on his country.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A destroyed house in Kyiv on Monday after Russia targeted the Ukrainian capital with a salvo of missiles.

item.title: Russian Opposition Leader Navalny Misses Court Date, Raising Alarm Among Supporters
item.description: The Russian opposition leader had been scheduled to appear before a district court via a video link on Monday. His spokeswoman said his allies had not heard from him for more than five days.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, second from left, with his lawyers in an image from a video link provided by the Russian Federal Penitentiary Service in August.

item.title: Kenya Hit by Third Major Blackout in Four Months
item.description: The outages have raised widespread concerns in a country already grappling with discontent over a worsening economic situation.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: A Kenya Airways plane at a 2022 air show in Nairobi. Power outages have in recent months disrupted operations at Kenya’s biggest airport.

item.title: Will Guatemala’s President-Elect, Bernardo Arévalo, Actually Take Office?
item.description: Bernardo Arévalo, the most progressive leader to get this far in decades, faces a barrage of legal attacks aimed at preventing an orderly transfer of power.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Jody García
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bernardo Arévalo, running on an anticorruption platform, won a landslide victory in Guatemala’s presidential race — but his adversaries in the legislative and judicial branches are stepping up efforts to bar him from taking office.

item.title: Ravaged Israeli Border Community Ponders: What’s Next?
item.description: Kibbutz Kfar Aza was devastated in the Hamas-led assault of Oct. 7, with its residents killed and kidnapped. Some see the prospects of its rehabilitation as a barometer for Israel’s future.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: A house that was destroyed during the Hamas attack on Kfar Aza on Oct. 7.

item.title: The Louvre Is Raising Ticket Prices Ahead of the Summer Olympics in Paris
item.description: The increase, going into effect in January, comes amid broader concerns about rising costs for lodging and transportation ahead of the Summer Olympics in Paris.
item.dc:creator: Orlando Mayorquin
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Louvre says its increased admission price is unconnected to the Paris Summer Olympics and is part of a broader plan already underway.

item.title: What It Feels Like To Be the Target of China’s Water Cannons
item.description: The Philippines invited journalists on a mission to provide fuel to fishermen in disputed waters of the South China Sea amid tensions between Beijing and Manila.
item.dc:creator: Camille Elemia
item.media:credit: Camille Elemia for The New York Times
item.media:description: China Coast Guard and maritime militia vessels using a water cannon towards a boat with Philippine officials on the way to reach the Scarborough shoal Saturday.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Conditions worsen in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A tent camp housing displaced Palestinians near a mosque in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip, on Saturday.

item.title: Gazans Mass at Border for Safety, but Find Only More Peril
item.description: As Israeli forces pound Gaza, the area where Palestinians can seek shelter is shrinking, raising concerns that they could be forced into Egypt.
item.dc:creator: Ameera Harouda, Ben Hubbard and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Palestinians fleeing Khan Younis toward Rafah passing a crater caused by strikes on Sunday.

item.title: Zelensky to Meet With Biden in Washington With U.S. Aid to Ukraine in Doubt
item.description: Officials announced that the Ukrainian president would travel to Washington on Tuesday for a last-ditch lobbying effort with President Biden and members of Congress.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Karoun Demirjian
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine last visited Washington in September.

item.title: Shlomo Avineri, Israeli Scholar Skeptical About Peace, Dies at 90
item.description: A former liberal government official, he saw little chance of full reconciliation with Palestinians in “the foreseeable future” but nevertheless sought to ease tensions.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: Dr. Gao Yaojie, Who Exposed AIDS Epidemic in Rural China, Dies at 95
item.description: Despite government efforts to silence her, she drew global attention to an epidemic that devastated rural China and killed tens of thousands.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Dr. Gao Yaojie talked with students during an AIDS lecture tour in Shanghai in 2006.

item.title: Netanyahu Speaks to Putin and Criticizes Cooperation Between Russia and Iran
item.description: It was the first call in weeks between the two leaders, whose relationship has been strained since the start of the Israel-Hamas war.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, in a photo released by Russian state media, spoke with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Sunday.

item.title: Berlin’s Vegan Food Scene Is Flourishing
item.description: Meatless menus used to be an oddity in Germany’s capital. Today, Berlin is bursting with creative vegan options, including Spanish tapas, Berliner-style doughnuts and even fast food.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preparing a maitake mushroom for a dish at Oukan, a vegan restaurant in Berlin.

item.title: Children of Jailed Narges Mohammadi Accept Her Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: At the ceremony in Oslo, the Iranian activist’s twins also read a speech from their mother calling for a “globalization of peace and human rights.”
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Fredrik Varfjell/NTB Scanpix, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The ceremony awarding the Nobel Peace Prize to Iranian activist Narges Mohammadi, shown on the screen, in Oslo, Norway, on Sunday.

item.title: What Can You Do With an Einstein?
item.description: Earlier this year, mathematicians discovered a unique shape. Now do-it-yourselfers have found ingenious ways to put it to use.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts

item.title: Who’s a ‘Colonizer’? How an Old Word Became a New Weapon
item.description: In bitter debates from Israel to Africa to America, invoking a brutal history has become a powerful accusation.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen

item.title: How Israel Secretly Propped Up Hamas
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu gambled that a strong Hamas (but not too strong) would keep the peace and reduce pressure for a Palestinian state.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Hamas fighters in 2021 in Gaza City.

item.title: Israel-Hamas War Has Buoyed Egypt’s Leader Ahead of Presidential Vote
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt grew increasingly unpopular amid a deep economic crisis. But the war in neighboring Gaza has given him a vital role on the international stage.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: A campaign poster in Cairo for the Egyptian president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi. The war in Gaza has shifted attention away from economic problems that were hobbling him.

item.title: A World Map With No National Borders and 1,642 Animals
item.description: Anton Thomas, a New Zealander in Melbourne, Australia, has given three years of his life to a hand-drawn map of our planet and its animal inhabitants.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Abigail Varney for The New York Times

item.title: ‘I left my good friends’: In videos shown in Tel Aviv, freed hostages share their stories.
item.description: Some of those who spent weeks in captivity addressed the cameras for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg

item.title: U.S. Is Criticized After Veto of U.N. Call for Gaza Cease-Fire
item.description: As fighting surged in the territory, Arab leaders condemned the move as a “mark of shame,” one that will haunt the United States for years.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim, Edward Wong and Thomas Fuller
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Battling flames in Khan Younis after an Israeli strike on Saturday. Humanitarian aid groups warned that thousands of children in the territory were at risk of dying of starvation.

item.title: Israeli Strikes Pound Gaza a Day after U.S. Vetoes Cease-Fire Resolution.
item.description: Some of the strikes targeted the southern Gaza Strip, where the Israeli military has ordered civilians to go to avoid bombardment.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:description: A boy tries to salvage some objects amid the rubble of a building hit by an Israeli strike, in Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip, on Saturday.

item.title: Mexico Shootout Kills 14 After Town Fights Back Against Cartel
item.description: At least 14 people were killed in a clash between the gunmen and members of a small farming community in central Mexico, an episode that the state authorities cast as a gang extortion attempt that backfired.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega

item.title: Yemen’s Houthi Militia Threatens to Block All Ships Headed to Israel
item.description: It was unclear to what extent the Iranian-backed militia, which controls northern Yemen, would be able to act on its expanded warning.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim and Shuaib Almosawa
item.media:description: The Houthis were still holding a commercial vessel, the Galaxy Leader, they hijacked last month.

item.title: State Department Bypasses Congress to Approve Israel’s Order for Tank Ammunition
item.description: It is the first time the Biden administration has declared an emergency to expedite arms shipments to the Middle East, which are controversial because of the civilian death toll from Israeli airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers working on their tank near the border with Gaza on Friday.

item.title: While Gazans Suffer, Hamas Reaps the Benefits
item.description: It has gained prestige among Palestinians while poisoning Israel’s relations with the Arab world and putting the Palestinian issue back on the Western agenda.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings this month in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip.
